unnormalised: Okay, so you're thinking of tackling the Indian Railways, eh? Buckle up, buttercup, because it's an experience. I mean, calling it an experience is like calling the monsoon a light drizzle. It's more like a full-blown, monsoon-level adventure.
normalised: Okay, so you are thinking of tackling the Indian Railways, eh? Buckle up, buttercup, because it is an experience. I mean, calling it an experience is like calling the monsoon a light drizzle. It is more like a full-blown, monsoon-level adventure.

unnormalised: First off, booking tickets. IRCTC. Those four letters strike fear into the hearts of even the bravest souls. Forget trying to book tatkal at 10:00 AM sharp. It's like the digital Hunger Games. The website will lag, crash, and probably insult your ancestors before you manage to maybe, possibly, snag a ticket. My personal record is refreshing the page 150 times in 3 minutes. Lost my cool and my train ticket. Pro tip: Book way in advance. I'm talking months. Like, book now for Diwali next year. Okay, maybe not that far, but you get the drift.

It is like the digital Hunger Games. The website will lag, crash, and probably insult your ancestors before you manage to maybe, possibly, snag a ticket. My personal record is refreshing the page one hundred and fifty times in three minutes. Lost my cool and my train ticket. Pro tip: Book way in advance. I am talking months. Like, book now for Diwali next year. Okay, maybe not that far, but you get the drift.

unnormalised: And then there's the waiting list. Ah, the WL. A cruel mistress. You might be WL 50, thinking, "No way I'm getting confirmed." But then, a miracle! Suddenly you're RAC (Reservation Against Cancellation). Then Confirmed! You've won the lottery! Except, the lottery is a seat on a train. This is all assuming the train isn't running late. Add at least 2 hours to any scheduled arrival time. "Indian Standard Time" is more of a suggestion than a rule.

unnormalised: Now, let’s talk about the actual journey. Get ready for a sensory overload. The sounds! The chaiwallahs yelling "Chai! Chai! Garam chai!", the constant announcements (usually unintelligible), and the rhythmic clatter of the train on the tracks. The smells! A potent mix of spices, sweat, diesel, and the occasional whiff of… well, let's just say things best left undescribed. Pack earplugs and maybe a nose clip (kidding... mostly). My friend once described it as "a symphony of chaos" and honestly, that's pretty accurate.

unnormalised: Don't forget the food. The pantry car food is...an experience. Let's just say that. Pre-packaged biryani at Rs. 150 might seem tempting when your stomach is rumbling, but proceed with caution. Carry your own snacks. Biscuits, chips, maybe some homemade theplas if you're feeling ambitious. And for the love of all that is holy, buy bottled water. You’ll thank me later. Also, be prepared to share. Passengers are incredibly generous, especially with snacks. It's a cultural thing. Refusing is practically an insult.

unnormalised: And the people! Oh, the stories you'll hear! Sharmaji from Delhi will tell you all about his son's engineering degree. Khan Sahab from Lucknow will share his poetry (whether you want him to or not). The aunty from Kerala will offer you homemade pickles. Embrace the conversations. It's part of the charm. Just try to avoid getting drawn into any political debates at 3:00 AM.

unnormalised: Finally, arriving at your destination. A chaotic swarm of coolies trying to grab your luggage, auto-rickshaws honking, and people everywhere. It’s overwhelming but exhilarating. You've survived the Indian Railways! Pat yourself on the back. You've earned it.

unnormalised: So, should you take the Indian Railways? Absolutely! Just go in with the right attitude, a sense of humor, and a willingness to embrace the madness. And pack wet wipes. Lots of wet wipes. I give it 5/5 stars, but 3/5 for punctuality. Just booked a ticket for 26/01/2025, wish me luck!
